title: 01 ‚Ä¢ Mesh Component Designer
summary: Master the mesh designer workflow to create custom 2D shapes for your game.

content.text: The mesh component designer is a powerful tool for creating custom 2D shapes that can be used as sprites, collision boundaries, or visual elements in your game. This tutorial covers advanced mesh design techniques and best practices.
Understanding Mesh Structure
A mesh in Nostalgi2D consists of:

items: Vertices: Points that define the shape (x, y coordinates)
Edges: Lines connecting vertices in order
Fill: The interior of the polygon defined by the vertices
Metadata: Properties like meshId and materialId

content.text: Creating Complex Shapes
Let's create a spaceship mesh with proper vertex winding:

items: Start at the top point of the ship (nose)
Add vertices moving counter-clockwise around the shape
Keep the shape convex - no inward-pointing angles
Use 5-8 vertices for most game objects

content.alt: Mesh designer showing a spaceship shape with labeled vertices
content.caption: Creating a spaceship mesh with proper counter-clockwise vertex order

content.text: üí° Counter-clockwise vertex order ensures proper rendering and collision detection. Most graphics APIs use this convention.
Working with the Canvas
The mesh designer canvas provides several tools to help you work precisely:

items: Grid Snapping: Hold Shift while placing vertices to snap to grid
Zoom: Use mouse wheel or zoom controls to see details
Pan: Click and drag the canvas background to move the view
Coordinates Display: Shows x,y position of your cursor

content.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è Vertices are defined in local space relative to the mesh center. Position (0,0) is the center of rotation.
Adding Metadata
Metadata helps you organize and reference meshes in your game code:

items: meshId: A unique identifier for this mesh (used in code)
materialId: Reference to a material/texture (for future use)
tags: Custom properties for categorization
description: Human-readable notes about the mesh

content.text: Set these properties in the Properties panel on the right side of the editor.

content.alt: Properties panel showing mesh metadata fields
content.caption: Configure mesh metadata in the Properties panel

content.text: Testing Your Mesh
Before using a mesh in your game, test it in the editor:

items: Use the preview mode to see how the mesh will render
Check that all vertices are visible and correctly positioned
Verify the mesh is convex by checking for inward angles
Test different scale factors to ensure it looks good at various sizes

content.text: Exporting Meshes
Once your mesh is ready, export it for use in your game runtime:
Mesh JSON files can be imported directly into your TypeScript code and used to create mesh components at runtime.
Best Practices

items: Keep meshes simple - use 3-8 vertices for best performance
Always use counter-clockwise vertex order
Center important meshes at (0,0) for predictable rotation
Use descriptive meshId names (e.g., 'player-ship', 'enemy-bullet')
Save frequently while designing complex meshes

content.text: Common Issues
If your mesh doesn't render correctly:

items: Check vertex order - should be counter-clockwise
Ensure the mesh is convex (no inward angles)
Verify all vertices have valid x,y coordinates
Check that meshId is unique and properly referenced in code

content.text: Next Steps
Now that you can create custom meshes, you're ready to use them in actual game code. Continue to the Hello World tutorial to learn how to create actors with mesh components and render them on screen.
